title: 105_hr3478
content: The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" provides for a final settlement of the claims of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes by agreeing to reduced water supply facilities. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" defines key terms such as Agreement, Animas-La Plata Project, Dolores Project, and Tribe/Tribes. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" includes amendments to the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 amended Section 6(a) of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 to provide for the construction of a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acre-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. This includes a pumping plant and reservoir inlet conduit for municipal and industrial water allocations. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 amended Section 6(a) of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 to provide for the construction of a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acre-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. This includes a pumping plant and reservoir inlet conduit for municipal and industrial water allocations to various tribes and the San Juan Water Commission. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocated water to the Navajo Nation, San Juan Water Commission, and Animas-La Plata Conservancy District with specific annual depletion limits. Tribal construction costs for water allocations are nonreimbursable. The nontribal municipal and industrial water capital repayment obligations for the Animas-La Plata Project shall be satisfied by specific entities with designated amounts, totaling $29,000,000. The State of Colorado will pay $16,000,000 towards the cost-sharing obligation for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement and Animas-La Plata Project. Certain costs for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resources, and fish and wildlife mitigation will not be reimbursed. Tribal water allocations for municipal and industrial use from the project are also specified. The Secretary will cover operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for tribal water allocations from the Animas-La Plata Project or Dolores Project until the water is used by the Tribe. Tribes are not required to reimburse these costs. The Tribe is not obligated to repay the Secretary for costs related to water allocations from the Dolores Project. Repayment of construction costs and sharing of operation costs begin when the water is first used by the Tribe. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to provide water allocations to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico. The Secretary shall take necessary action to allocate water not to exceed 5,230 acre-feet annually to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to allocate water to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico. The Secretary will allocate up to 5,230 acre-feet annually to Colorado and up to 780 acre-feet annually to New Mexico. Additional water depletions consistent with the Endangered Species Act may be allocated among beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project based on agreements among them. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to allocate water to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico. The Secretary will allocate water among beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project based on agreements, and may transfer water rights to fulfill New Mexico's purposes. The Interstate Stream Commission may transfer water rights under New Mexico Engineer permit number 2883 to fulfill the New Mexico purposes of the Animas La-Plata Project. Certain reports like the Final Supplement to the Final Environmental Impact Statement and the Final Biological Opinion are considered adequate to meet requirements under various acts. The Final Supplement to the Final Environmental Impact Statement and the Final Biological Opinion are considered adequate to meet requirements under various acts for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, construction of described facilities, and an aggregate depletion of 57,100 acre-feet of water. The provision of water to the Tribes in accordance with this section shall constitute final settlement of the tribal claims to water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. Nothing in this subsection shall affect the construction of facilities not described here or any use of water not approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Final settlement of tribal water rights on Animas and La Plata Rivers. No impact on other tribal water rights or participation in projects. Attorney General to file necessary instruments for court decree amendments. The Attorney General of the United States will file necessary instruments with the District Court, Water Division Number 7 in Colorado to request amendments to the final consent decree regarding tribal water rights settlement on Animas and La Plata Rivers. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION; TREATMENT OF CERTAIN FUNDS. The amendments made by this Act to section 6 of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement of 1988 do not affect the applicability of other provisions of that Act or the Secretary of the Interior's obligation to deliver water from the Dolores Project and complete construction of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation as described in specific appropriations acts. The Department of the Interior appropriations acts from 1992 to 1995 and the treatment of the uncommitted portion of Colorado's cost-sharing obligation are addressed in the text. The uncommitted portion of Colorado's cost-sharing obligation under the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 can be used to fund components of the Animas-La Plata Project not covered in the Act.
